docs.abstract: Microsoft Corp holds its 25th-birthday party; about 20,000 employees gather at Safeco Field in Seattle for entertainment and pep talk by company's founder, William H Gates; photo (S)
docs.snippet: Microsoft Corp holds its 25th-birthday party; about 20,000 employees gather at Safeco Field in Seattle for entertainment and pep talk by company's founder, William H Gates; photo (S)...

docs.abstract: National Science Foundation makes $45 million grant to Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center to buy from Compaq what manufacturer says will be world's fastest nonmilitary supercomputer when installed in 2001 (M)
docs.snippet: The National Science Foundation announced yesterday that it had made a $45 million award to the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center to buy from Compaq what the computer maker says will be the world's fastest nonmilitary supercomputer when it is insta...
docs.lead_paragraph: The National Science Foundation announced yesterday that it had made a $45 million award to the Pittsburgh Supercomputing Center to buy from Compaq what the computer maker says will be the world's fastest nonmilitary supercomputer when it is installed next year. The award, which was announced yesterday in Washington after the foundation reviewed proposals from five scientific centers, is intended to reinvigorate the nation's civilian computational science resources, which have increasingly fallen behind the resources available to the military in recent years.

headline.main: $45 Million Grant Awarded to Buy Supercomputer

docs.abstract: Lawyers for eight movie studios urge Judge Lewis Kaplan to keep Eric Corley from distributing on his Web site software program that unscrambles encryption on DVD movie discs (M)
docs.snippet: On the first day of a case that could test the limits of Hollywood's control over its digital properties, lawyers for eight movie studios yesterday urged a federal judge to stop a Web site operator from distributing a software program that unscram...
docs.lead_paragraph: On the first day of a case that could test the limits of Hollywood's control over its digital properties, lawyers for eight movie studios yesterday urged a federal judge to stop a Web site operator from distributing a software program that unscrambles the encryption on DVD movie discs. The lawyers asked the court to act before they have the same fate as the record labels, which have seen their songs traded freely by millions of Internet users. The studios are seeking to show that Eric Corley, publisher of 2600, a computer hacker magazine and Web site, violated the law by posting on his Web site, and linking to other Web sites that do the same, a program that breaks the code called CSS, or Content Scrambling System, on DVD's. Once the program, known as DeCSS, is invoked, a movie can be copied and sent across the Internet.

headline.main: Movie Studios Seek to Stop DVD Copies

docs.abstract: Netscape Communications prepares to roll out first major upgrade of its Internet browser since Aug 1997; parent, America Online, sees brower as key to series of interactive consumer services, with many of new browser features tied to AOL strengths; seeks to combat reports that Netscape, which lost nearly all of its top management and much of its engineering staff, is in disarray; photos (M)
docs.snippet: Remember the browser war?    Throughout the early years of the World Wide Web, there was a ferocious battle between Netscape Communications, developer of the first commercial Internet browser, and Microsoft as the companies introduced a rapid seri...
docs.lead_paragraph: Remember the browser war? Throughout the early years of the World Wide Web, there was a ferocious battle between Netscape Communications, developer of the first commercial Internet browser, and Microsoft as the companies introduced a rapid series of improved products.

headline.main: Netscape Browser Faces a Changed World

docs.abstract: Campaign of Republican presidential candidate Sen John McCain and Republican Party have released new recording that alludes to television special asserting that Democratic presidential candidate Sen Barack Obama's 'list of friends reads like history of radicalism'; assertion is made on special Fox news television program Hannity's America, hosted by Sean Hannity; photo (M)
docs.snippet: The campaign of Senator John McCain and the Republican Party have released a new recording that alludes to a television special asserting that Senator Barack Obama's ''list of friends reads like a history of radicalism.''     That assertion was ma...
docs.lead_paragraph: The campaign of Senator John McCain and the Republican Party have released a new recording that alludes to a television special asserting that Senator Barack Obama's ''list of friends reads like a history of radicalism.'' That assertion was made on a special ''Hannity's America'' on Fox News on Oct. 5, hosted by Sean Hannity, right.

docs.abstract: HD Radio, which rivals satellite radio quality and promises to eliminate static, digitizes and compresses station's signal; stream is then broadcast in same frequency range used for analog transmissions; to get HD, users need tuner that can detect and decode digital transmissions; several car options noted; difference between analog and HD broadcasts is easily discerned in New York City; photos (M)
docs.snippet: AS drivers pick their way down the West Side Highway of Manhattan, the noise is often more annoying than the traffic -- and it's not just the honking.      What's so irksome is the static from the car's sound system, a result of congestion in the ...
docs.lead_paragraph: AS drivers pick their way down the West Side Highway of Manhattan, the noise is often more annoying than the traffic -- and it's not just the honking. What's so irksome is the static from the car's sound system, a result of congestion in the radio frequency spectrum in an area packed with AM and FM stations. But that analog annoyance may fade away as radio broadcasters, carmakers and consumer electronics companies make the transition to digital radio.

headline.main: Local Radio Is Cutting the Static and Going Digital, Finally

docs.abstract: France Weighs Forcing iPods to Play Other Tha8
docs.snippet: A bill under debate in the French Parliament may require iPods to be able to play music purchased from competing Internet services, not just Apple Computer's own iTunes Music Store....
docs.lead_paragraph: In the digital music market, France is singing a different tune. A bill under debate in the French Parliament may require iPods to be able to play music purchased from competing Internet services, not just Apple Computer's own iTunes Music Store, forcing changes in the business model that gave rise to the revolution in legal digital music downloads.

headline.main: France Weighs Forcing iPods to Play Other Than iTunes

docs.abstract: Sen Ron Wyden will introduce legislation that would prohibit Internet network operators from charging companies for faster delivery of their content to consumers or favoring some content providers over others; bill is meant to ease growing fears that open Internet access may be blocked or compromised by Bell phone carriers and cable operators, which may create tiers of service for delivering content to consumers; consumer groups and Internet companies like Google and Amazon contend that any move by network operators to levy fees for premium delivery service would harm Web sites that are unwilling to pay for faster delivery; Federal Communications Commission has remained neutral on issue (M)
docs.snippet: New legislation would prohibit Internet network operators from charging for faster delivery or favoring some content providers over others....
docs.lead_paragraph: Senator Ron Wyden, Democrat of Oregon, will introduce new legislation today that would prohibit Internet network operators from charging companies for faster delivery of their content to consumers or favoring some content providers over others. The bill is meant to ease growing fears that open Internet access may be blocked or compromised by the Bell phone carriers and cable operators, which may create tiers of service for delivering content to consumers, much the way the post office charges more for overnight mail delivery than for regular delivery.

headline.main: Senate Bill to Address Fears of Blocked Access to Net

docs.abstract: Qualcomm says earnings rose 37 percent in its fourth quarter, to $538 million; revenue rose 40 percent, to $1.56 billion (S)
docs.snippet: SAN DIEGO, Nov. 2 (Dow Jones/AP) - Qualcomm reported Wednesday that its earnings rose 37 percent in its latest quarter, led by demand for next-generation cellphones....
docs.lead_paragraph: Qualcomm reported Wednesday that its earnings rose 37 percent in its latest quarter, led by demand for next-generation cellphones. The company, which makes chips for cellphones and licenses the wireless technology it created, also said that results for the current quarter would beat analysts' expectations.

docs.abstract: Carnegie Mellon University, Intel and SpikeSource devise rating system intended to reduce confusion and guesswork in evaluating free software (M)
docs.snippet: Carnegie Mellon University, Intel and SpikeSource have devised a rating system intended to reduce the confusion and guesswork for corporate engineers in evaluating open-source software....
docs.lead_paragraph: Free software, despite the price, can be confusing and costly for corporations to use. A few freely distributed programs, like the Linux operating system and the Apache Web server, have become well known, but most are still unproved. So companies often have to do their own testing and tweaking to see if such open-source programs -- free software available for programmers to modify or enhance -- work reliably. That obstacle has slowed the software's advance.

headline.main: Rating System Will Evaluate Free Software
